        V-204405 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that /etc/pam.d/passwd implements /etc/pam.d/system-auth when changing passwords.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204405r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010118
        Identities:SV-95715
        V-81003
        CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
        Description: Pluggable authentication modules (PAM) allow for a modular approach to integrating authentication methods. PAM operates in a top-down processing model and if the modules are not listed in the correct order, an important security function could be bypassed if stack entries are not centralized. false
        Fix Text:Configure PAM to utilize /etc/pam.d/system-auth when changing passwords.

        Add the following line to "/etc/pam.d/passwd" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        password substack system-auth
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95715
        Result:true
        Title:Verify /etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd
        Description:/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9571500 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:/etc/pam.d/system-auth is included in /etc/pam.d/passwd.
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9571500 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename must be equal to 'passwd'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*password[ \t]+substack[ \t]+system-auth\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/passwd'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'passwd'
        • pattern equals '^[\s]*password[ \t]+substack[ \t]+system-auth\s*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'password substack system-auth'
        • line equals 'password substack system-auth'
        • subexpression does not exist

        V-204406 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, pwquality must be used.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204406r902704_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010119
        Identities:SV-87811
        V-73159
        CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to use "pwquality" to enforce password complexity rules.

        Add the following line to "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        password requisite pam_pwquality.so retry=3

        Note: The value of "retry" should be between "1" and "3".
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7os:def:204406
        Result:true
        Title:RHEL-07-010119 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, pwquality must be used.
        Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:25171400 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:25171400 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:20000018 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[123]$'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'system-auth'
        • pattern equals '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 '
        • line equals 'password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 '
        • subexpression equals '3'

        V-204407 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one upper-case character.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204407r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010120
        Identities:SV-86527
        V-71903
        CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one upper-case character be used by setting the "ucredit" option.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        ucredit = -1
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:484
        Result:false
        Title:Set Password ucredit Requirements
        Description:The password ucredit should meet minimum requirements
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:485 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2372 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^ucredit[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2373 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be less than or equal to '-1'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'system-auth'
        • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • line equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • subexpression does not exist

        V-204408 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed or new passwords are established, the new password must contain at least one lower-case character.

        V-204411 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of eight of the total number of characters must be changed.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204411r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010160
        Identities:V-71911
        SV-86535
        CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least eight of the total number of characters when passwords are changed by setting the "difok" option.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        difok = 8

        Weight:10.0

        V-204412 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed a minimum of four character classes must be changed.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204412r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010170
        Identities:V-71913
        SV-86537
        CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed by setting the "minclass" option.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        minclass = 4

        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2363 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '4'

        Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'system-auth'
        • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • line equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • subexpression does not exist

        V-204413 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating consecutive characters must not be more than three characters.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204413r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010180
        Identities:SV-86539
        V-71915
        CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating consecutive characters when passwords are changed by setting the "maxrepeat" option.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        maxrepeat = 3
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:472
        Result:false
        Title:Set Password maxrepeat Requirements
        Description:The password maxrepeat should meet minimum
        requirements using pam_pwquality
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:473 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2360 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^maxrepeat[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2361 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'system-auth'
        • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • line equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • subexpression does not exist

        V-204414 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that when passwords are changed the number of repeating characters of the same character class must not be more than four characters.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204414r809186_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010190
        Identities:SV-86541
        V-71917
        CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
        Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

        maxclassrepeat = 4
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899

        Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

        Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.
        Class:compliance

          • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)

        State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2358 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^maxclassrepeat[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

          • subexpression must be less than or equal to '4'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:47000 (textfilecontent54_state)

        V-204415 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the PAM system service is configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204415r880833_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010200
        Identities:V-71919
        SV-86543
        CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
        Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

        Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth":
        pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok

        Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth":
        pam_unix.so sha512 shadow try_first_pass use_authtok

        Note: Per requirement RHEL-07-010199, RHEL 7 must be configured to not overwrite custom authentication configuration settings while using the authconfig utility, otherwise manual changes to the listed files will be overwritten whenever the authconfig utility is used.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1367
        Result:true
        Title:Set Password Hashing Algorithm in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Description:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check /etc/pam.d/system-auth for correct settings)
          • true (check /etc/pam.d/system-auth for md5, sha256, blowfish, or bigcrypt in the password require|sufficient pam_unix.so lines) (negated)
          • true (check /etc/pam.d/password-auth for correct settings)
          • true (check /etc/pam.d/password-auth for md5, sha256, blowfish, or bigcrypt in the password require|sufficient pam_unix.so lines) (negated)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1368 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:check /etc/pam.d/system-auth for correct settings
        Check Existence:One and only one collected item may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3057 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename must be equal to 'system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:sufficient))[ \t]+pam_unix\.so(.*)$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:3057 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]))sha512(?:\s|$)'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'

        V-204416 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to use the shadow file to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204416r877397_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010210
        Identities:V-71921
        SV-86545
        CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
        Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

        Add or update the following line in "/etc/login.defs":

        ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1365
        Result:true
        Title:Set SHA512 Password Hashing Algorithm in /etc/login.defs
        Description:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/login.defs.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (The value of ENCRYPT_METHOD should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1366 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:The value of ENCRYPT_METHOD should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3759 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*ENCRYPT_METHOD\s+(\w+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:3056 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'SHA512'

        • path equals '/etc'
        • filename equals 'login.defs'

        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512

          '
        • line equals 'ENCRYPT_METHOD SHA512

          '
        • subexpression equals 'SHA512'

        V-204417 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that user and group account administration utilities are configured to store only encrypted representations of passwords.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204417r877397_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010220
        Identities:V-71923
        SV-86547
        CCI-000196 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (c); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (c))
        Description: Passwords need to be protected at all times, and encryption is the standard method for protecting passwords. If passwords are not encrypted, they can be plainly read (i.e., clear text) and easily compromised. Passwords encrypted with a weak algorithm are no more protected than if they are kept in plain text. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to store only SHA512 encrypted representations of passwords.

        Add or update the following line in "/etc/libuser.conf" in the [defaults] section:

        crypt_style = sha512
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1363
        Result:true
        Title:Set SHA512 Password Hashing Algorithm in /etc/libuser.conf
        Description:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/libuser.conf.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/libuser.conf)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1364 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:The password hashing algorithm should be set correctly in /etc/libuser.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3054 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/libuser.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*crypt_style[\s]+=[\s]+(\S+)[\s]*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:3054 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Ss][Hh][Aa]512$'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/libuser.conf'
        • path equals '/etc'
        • filename equals 'libuser.conf'
        • pattern equals '^[\s]*crypt_style[\s]+=[\s]+(\S+)[\s]*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals '
          crypt_style = sha512'
        • line equals '
          crypt_style = sha512'
        • subexpression equals 'sha512'

        V-204418 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204418r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010230
        Identities:V-71925
        SV-86549
        CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
        Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.

        Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        PASS_MIN_DAYS 1
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:455
        Result:false
        Title:Set Password Expiration Parameters
        Description:The minimum password age policy should be set appropriately.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:456 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3730 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2346 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, at least one of the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ false ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
        • path equals '/etc'
        • filename equals 'login.defs'
        • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
        • line equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
        • subexpression equals '0'
        Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
        subexpression

        V-204419 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are restricted to a 24 hours/1 day minimum lifetime.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204419r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010240
        Identities:SV-86551
        V-71927
        CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
        Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
        Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime:

        # chage -m 1 [user]
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86551
        Result:false
        Title:Passwords must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
        Description:Passwords must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.)
          • true (no shadow entries with null minimum password ages)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8655100 (shadow_test)
        Result:false
        Title:Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 1 day minimum lifetime.
        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8655100 (shadow_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • for username, at least one of the following must be true:
          • username must be equal to 'vagrant'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8655100 (shadow_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', chg_allow must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ false ]
        • username equals 'vagrant'
        • password equals [MASKED PASSWORD FIELD]
        • chg_lst equals '19445'
        • chg_allow equals '0'
        • chg_req equals '99999'
        • exp_warn equals '7'
        • exp_inact equals ''
        • exp_date equals ''
        • flag equals ''
        • encrypt_method equals 'SHA-512'
        Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
        chg_allow
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8655101 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:no shadow entries with null minimum password ages
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8655102 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
        • for pattern, at least one of the following must be true:
          • pattern must match the pattern '^vagrant:[^:]*:[^:]*::'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

        V-204420 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords for new users are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204420r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010250
        Identities:V-71929
        SV-86553
        CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
        Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

        Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        PASS_MAX_DAYS 60
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:453
        Result:false
        Title:Set Password Expiration Parameters
        Description:The maximum password age policy should meet minimum requirements.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (The value of PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:454 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:The value of PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3729 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2344 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, at least one of the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ false ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
        • path equals '/etc'
        • filename equals 'login.defs'
        • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d+)\s*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
        • line equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
        • subexpression equals '99999'
        Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
        subexpression

        V-204421 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204421r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010260
        Identities:V-71931
        SV-86555
        CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
        Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised. false
        Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

        # chage -M 60 [user]
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899

        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Passwords for interactive users must be restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.)

            • true (no null max pw ages.)
          • false (interactive users exist.) (negated)

        Include Items If:
        • user_id is greater than or equal to '1000'

          • user_id does not equal '65534'

        • home_dir equals '/home/vagrant'
        • login_shell equals '/bin/bash'
        • last_login equals '0'

        V-204422 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are prohibited from reuse for a minimum of five generations.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204422r880836_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010270
        Identities:V-71933
        SV-86557
        CCI-000200 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (e); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (e))
        Description: Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to consecutively reuse their password when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

        Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" and "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3

        Note: Per requirement RHEL-07-010199, RHEL 7 must be configured to not overwrite custom authentication configuration settings while using the authconfig utility, otherwise manual changes to the listed files will be overwritten whenever the authconfig utility is used.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:486
        Result:false
        Title:Limit Password Reuse
        Description:The passwords to remember should be set correctly.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
          • false (Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:488 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2376 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:requisite)|(?:required))\s+pam_pwhistory\.so[^#\n\r]*remember=([0-9]*).*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2375 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:48800 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:Test if remember attribute of pam_pwhistory.so is set correctly in /etc/pam.d/password-auth
        Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:237600 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:requisite)|(?:required))\s+pam_pwhistory\.so[^#\n\r]*remember=([0-9]*).*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2375 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204423 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that passwords are a minimum of 15 characters in length.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204423r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010280
        Identities:V-71935
        SV-86559
        CCI-000205 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (i); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
        Description: The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

        Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to exponentially increase the time and/or resources required to compromise the password. false
        Fix Text:Configure operating system to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.

        Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        minlen = 15
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:476
        Result:false
        Title:Set Password minlen Requirements
        Description:The password minlen should meet minimum requirements
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:477 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/security/pwquality.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2364 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/pwquality.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^minlen[\s]*=[\s]*(-?\d+)(?:[\s]|$)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2365 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', instance must be equal to '1'
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '15'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:480 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:check the configuration of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2368 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
        • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
        • filename equals 'system-auth'
        • pattern equals '^\s*password\s+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))\s+pam_pwquality\.so.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • line equals '
          password requisite pam_pwquality.so try_first_pass local_users_only retry=3 authtok_type='
        • subexpression does not exist

        V-204426 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) if the password expires.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204426r809190_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010310
        Identities:SV-86565
        V-71941
        CCI-000795 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-4 e; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-4.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-4 e)
        Description: Inactive identifiers pose a risk to systems and applications because attackers may exploit an inactive identifier and potentially obtain undetected access to the system. Owners of inactive accounts will not notice if unauthorized access to their user account has been obtained.

        Operating systems need to track periods of inactivity and disable application identifiers after 35 days of inactivity. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) 35 days after the password expires.

        Add the following line to "/etc/default/useradd" (or modify the line to have the required value):

        INACTIVE=35
        DoD recommendation is 35 days, but a lower value is acceptable. The value "-1" will disable this feature, and "0" will disable the account immediately after the password expires.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:443
        Result:false
        Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) if the password expires.
        Description:Inactive identifiers pose a risk to systems and applications because attackers may exploit an inactive identifier and potentially obtain undetected access to the system. Owners of inactive accounts will not notice if unauthorized access to their user account has been obtained.

        Operating systems need to track periods of inactivity and disable application identifiers after zero35 days of inactivity.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (the value INACTIVE parameter should be set appropriately in /etc/default/useradd)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:444 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:the value INACTIVE parameter should be set appropriately in /etc/default/useradd
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2333 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/default/useradd'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*INACTIVE\s*=\s*(\d+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2334 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '35'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2335 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '0'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204429 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that users must provide a password for privilege escalation.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204429r861003_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010340
        Identities:V-71947
        SV-86571
        CCI-002038 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-11)
        Description: Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

        When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the user re-authenticate.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00158 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require users to supply a password for privilege escalation.

        Check the configuration of the "/etc/sudoers" file with the following command:
        $ sudo visudo

        Remove any occurrences of "NOPASSWD" tags in the file.

        Check the configuration of the /etc/sudoers.d/* files with the following command:
        $ sudo grep -ir nopasswd /etc/sudoers.d

        Remove any occurrences of "NOPASSWD" tags in the file.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:176
        Result:false
        Title:Ensure NOPASSWD Is Not Used in Sudo
        Description:Checks sudo usage without password
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (NOPASSWD does not exist /etc/sudoers)
          • false (NOPASSWD does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:177 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:NOPASSWD does not exist /etc/sudoers
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2108 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:178 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:NOPASSWD does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2109 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/sudoers.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/sudoers.d/vagrant'
        • path equals '/etc/sudoers.d'
        • filename equals 'vagrant'
        • pattern equals '^(?!#).*[\s]+NOPASSWD[\s]*\:.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'vagrant ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL'
        • line equals 'vagrant ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL'
        • subexpression does not exist
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204430 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that users must re-authenticate for privilege escalation.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204430r853885_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010350
        Identities:V-71949
        SV-86573
        CCI-002038 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-11)
        Description: Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

        When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the user reauthenticate.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00156, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00157, SRG-OS-000373-GPOS-00158 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require users to reauthenticate for privilege escalation.

        Check the configuration of the "/etc/sudoers" file with the following command:

        # visudo
        Remove any occurrences of "!authenticate" tags in the file.

        Check the configuration of the "/etc/sudoers.d/*" files with the following command:

        # grep -i authenticate /etc/sudoers /etc/sudoers.d/*
        Remove any occurrences of "!authenticate" tags in the file(s).
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:173
        Result:true
        Title:Ensure !authenticate Is Not Used in Sudo
        Description:Checks sudo usage without authentication
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (!authenticate does not exist in /etc/sudoers)
          • true (!authenticate does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:174 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:!authenticate does not exist in /etc/sudoers
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2106 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+\!\s*authenticate.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:175 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:!authenticate does not exist in /etc/sudoers.d
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2107 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/sudoers.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^(?!#).*[\s]+\!\s*authenticate.*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'

        V-204431 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the delay between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt is at least four seconds.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204431r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010430
        Identities:SV-86575
        V-71951
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: Configuring the operating system to implement organization-wide security implementation guides and security checklists verifies compliance with federal standards and establishes a common security baseline across DoD that reflects the most restrictive security posture consistent with operational requirements.

        Configuration settings are the set of parameters that can be changed in hardware, software, or firmware components of the system that affect the security posture and/or functionality of the system. Security-related parameters are those parameters impacting the security state of the system, including the parameters required to satisfy other security control requirements. Security-related parameters include, for example, registry settings; account, file, and directory permission settings; and settings for functions, ports, protocols, services, and remote connections. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce a delay of at least four seconds between logon prompts following a failed console logon attempt.

        Modify the "/etc/login.defs" file to set the "FAIL_DELAY" parameter to "4" or greater:

        FAIL_DELAY 4
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

        Result:false
        Title:Ensure that FAIL_DELAY is Configured in /etc/login.defs
        Description:The delay between failed authentication attempts should be
        set for all users specified in /etc/login.defs
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (check FAIL_DELAY in /etc/login.defs)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:102 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:check FAIL_DELAY in /etc/login.defs
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2055 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*FAIL_DELAY[\s]+([^#\s]*)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be greater than or equal to '4'

        V-204434 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow users to override SSH environment variables.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204434r877377_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010460
        Identities:SV-86581
        V-71957
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: Failure to restrict system access to authenticated users negatively impacts operating system security. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to not allow users to override environment variables to the SSH daemon.

        Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for "PermitUserEnvironment" keyword and set the value to "no":

        PermitUserEnvironment no

        The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1385
        Result:false
        Title:Do Not Allow Users to Set Environment Options
        Description:PermitUserEnvironment should be disabled
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (Check value of PermitUserEnvironment in /etc/ssh/sshd_config)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (package openssh-server is removed)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1386 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:Check value of PermitUserEnvironment in /etc/ssh/sshd_config
        Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3066 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*(?i)PermitUserEnvironment(?-i)[\s]+(\w*)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:138600 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal (case insensitive) to 'no'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1269 (rpminfo_test)
        Result:false
        Title:package openssh-server is removed
        Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2994 (rpminfo_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • name must be equal to 'openssh-server'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • name equals 'openssh-server'
        • arch equals 'x86_64'
        • epoch equals '(none)'

        V-204435 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow a non-certificate trusted host SSH logon to the system.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204435r877377_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-010470
        Identities:SV-86583
        V-71959
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: Failure to restrict system access to authenticated users negatively impacts operating system security. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to not allow a non-certificate trusted host SSH logon to the system.

        Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for "HostbasedAuthentication" keyword and set the value to "no":

        HostbasedAuthentication no

        The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

        V-204437 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204437r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-010481
        Identities:V-77823
        SV-92519
        CCI-000213 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-3)
        Description: If the system does not require valid root authentication before it boots into single-user or maintenance mode, anyone who invokes single-user or maintenance mode is granted privileged access to all files on the system. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.

        Add or modify the "ExecStart" line in "/usr/lib/systemd/system/rescue.service" to include "/usr/sbin/sulogin":

        ExecStart=-/bin/sh -c "/usr/sbin/sulogin; /usr/bin/systemctl --fail --no-block default"
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:92519
        Result:true
        Title:Require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
        Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check in /usr/lib/systemd/system/rescue.service for the option /usr/sbin/sulogin assinged to ExecStart)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9251900 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:check in /usr/lib/systemd/system/rescue.service for the option /usr/sbin/sulogin assinged to ExecStart
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9251900 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/usr/lib/systemd/system'
        • filename must be equal to 'rescue.service'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*ExecStart=([^\n#]+)$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:9251900 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '['"; ]*\/usr\/sbin\/sulogin['"; ]*'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/usr/lib/systemd/system/rescue.service'
        • path equals '/usr/lib/systemd/system'
        • filename equals 'rescue.service'
        • pattern equals '^\s*ExecStart=([^\n#]+)$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'ExecStart=-/bin/sh -c "/usr/sbin/sulogin; /usr/bin/systemctl --fail --no-block default"'
        • line equals 'ExecStart=-/bin/sh -c "/usr/sbin/sulogin; /usr/bin/systemctl --fail --no-block default"'
        • subexpression equals '-/bin/sh -c "/usr/sbin/sulogin; /usr/bin/systemctl --fail --no-block default"'

        V-204445 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a file integrity tool verifies the baseline operating system configuration at least weekly.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204445r902698_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-020030
        Identities:SV-86597
        V-71973
        CCI-001744 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-3 (5); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-3 (5))
        Description: Unauthorized changes to the baseline configuration could make the system vulnerable to various attacks or allow unauthorized access to the operating system. Changes to operating system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be relevant to security.

        Detecting such changes and providing an automated response can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of the operating system. The operating system's Information System Security Manager (ISSM)/Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and System Administrators (SAs) must be notified via email and/or monitoring system trap when there is an unauthorized modification of a configuration item. false
        Fix Text:Configure the file integrity tool to run automatically on the system at least weekly.

        The following example output is generic. It will set cron to run AIDE daily, but other file integrity tools may be used:

        # more /etc/cron.daily/aide
        #!/bin/bash

        /usr/sbin/aide --check | /bin/mail -s "$HOSTNAME - Daily AIDE integrity check run" root@example_server_name.mil

        Note: Per requirement RHEL-07-020028, the "mailx" package must be installed on the system to enable email functionality.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7os:def:204445
        Result:false
        Title:RHEL-07-020030 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a file integrity tool verifies the baseline operating system configuration at least weekly.
        Description:Unauthorized changes to the baseline configuration could make the system vulnerable to various attacks or allow unauthorized access to the operating system. Changes to operating system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be relevant to security.

        Detecting such changes and providing an automated response can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of the operating system. The operating system's Information System Security Manager (ISSM)/Information System Security Officer (ISSO) and System Administrators (SAs) must be notified via email and/or monitoring system trap when there is an unauthorized modification of a configuration item.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with /etc/crontab)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with /etc/cron.d)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with /var/spool/cron/root)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with cron.daily)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with cron.weekly)
              • false (AIDE is configured to run daily with cron.hourly)
            • false (AIDE package is installed)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:20444501 (textfilecontent54_test)

        Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        State Operator:One or more item-state comparisons may be true.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:20444501 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/crontab'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*([\S]+[ \t]+[\S]+[ \t]+\*[ \t]+\*[ \t]+[\S]+)[ \t]+root[ \t]+\/usr\/sbin\/aide[ \t]+\-\-check(?:[\s]+|[\>\|]|$)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
