        V-204449 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to disable USB mass storage.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204449r853891_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-020100
        Identities:SV-86607
        V-71983
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        CCI-000778 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-3.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
        CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
        Description: USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000114-GPOS-00059, SRG-OS-000378-GPOS-00163, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the USB Storage kernel module.

        Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

        # touch /etc/modprobe.d/usb-storage.conf

        Add the following line to the created file:

        install usb-storage /bin/true

        Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use USB mass storage devices.

        # vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

        Add or update the line:

        blacklist usb-storage
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1141
        Result:false
        Title:Disable usb-storage Kernel Module
        Description:The kernel module usb-storage should be disabled.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (kernel module usb-storage disabled)
          • false (kernel module usb-storage blacklisted in /etc/modprobe.d)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1142 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:kernel module usb-storage disabled
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2892 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '^.*\.conf$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*install\s+usb-storage\s+(\S+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8660700 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '/bin/true'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8660700 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:kernel module usb-storage blacklisted in /etc/modprobe.d
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8660700 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '^.*\.conf$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*blacklist\s+usb-storage\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204450 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) kernel module is disabled unless required.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204450r853892_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-020101
        Identities:V-77821
        SV-92517
        CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
        Description: Disabling DCCP protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in the protocol implementation. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the DCCP kernel module.

        Create a file under "/etc/modprobe.d" with the following command:

        # touch /etc/modprobe.d/dccp.conf

        Add the following line to the created file:

        install dccp /bin/true

        Ensure that the DCCP module is blacklisted:

        # vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

        Add or update the line:

        blacklist dccp
        Severity:medium

        V-204451 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must disable the file system automounter unless required.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204451r853893_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-020110
        Identities:V-71985
        SV-86609
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        CCI-000778 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-3.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
        CCI-001958 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
        Description: Automatically mounting file systems permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000114-GPOS-00059, SRG-OS-000378-GPOS-00163, SRG-OS-000480-GPOS-00227 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to automount devices.

        Turn off the automount service with the following commands:

        # systemctl stop autofs
        # systemctl disable autofs

        If "autofs" is required for Network File System (NFS), it must be documented with the ISSO.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86609
        Result:true
        Title:File system automounter must be disabled unless required.
        Description:Automatically mounting file systems permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check for automount)
        Tests:

        Result:true

        • pid must be greater than '1'

        V-204457 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204457r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-020240
        Identities:SV-86619
        V-71995
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: Setting the most restrictive default permissions ensures that when new accounts are created, they do not have unnecessary access. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.

        Add or edit the line for the "UMASK" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" file to "077":

        UMASK 077
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:518
        Result:true
        Title:RHEL-07-020240 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must define default permissions for all authenticated users in such a way that the user can only read and modify their own files.
        Description:Setting the most restrictive default permissions ensures that when new accounts are created, they do not have unnecessary access.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (/etc/login.defs:UMASK == 077)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:51800 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:/etc/login.defs:UMASK == 077
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3737 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*(?i)UMASK(?-i)[\s]+([^#\s]*)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:51800 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '077'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]

        • path equals '/etc'
        • filename equals 'login.defs'
        • pattern equals '^[\s]*(?i)UMASK(?-i)[\s]+([^#\s]*)'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'UMASK 077'
        • line equals 'UMASK 077'
        • subexpression equals '077'

        Version:RHEL-07-020610

        Description: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to assign home directories to all new local interactive users by setting the "CREATE_HOME" parameter in "/etc/login.defs" to "yes" as follows.

        CREATE_HOME yes

        V-204467 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive users have a home directory assigned and defined in the /etc/passwd file.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204467r603826_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-020620
        Identities:V-72015
        SV-86639
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: If local interactive users are not assigned a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they should own.

        In addition, if a local interactive user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given access to the / directory as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a Denial of Service because the user would not be able to access their logon configuration files, and it may give them visibility to system files they normally would not be able to access. false
        Fix Text:Create home directories to all local interactive users that currently do not have a home directory assigned. Use the following commands to create the user home directory assigned in "/etc/ passwd":

        Note: The example will be for the user smithj, who has a home directory of "/home/smithj", a UID of "smithj", and a Group Identifier (GID) of "users" assigned in "/etc/passwd".

        # mkdir /home/smithj
        # chown smithj /home/smithj
        # chgrp users /home/smithj
        # chmod 0750 /home/smithj
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86639
        Result:true
        Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive user home directories are defined in the /etc/passwd file.
        Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all local interactive user home directories are defined in the /etc/passwd file.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (Verify all user home directories exist)
          • true (Verify root's home directory exists)
          • true (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (check for users without a home directory not defined)
            • true (check if root's home directory is not defined)

        • path equals '/home/vagrant'

        • type equals 'directory'

        • user_id equals '1000'

        • c_time equals '1694463363'

        • last_login equals '0'

        V-204482 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on file systems that are being imported via Network File System (NFS).

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204482r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-021020
        Identities:SV-86669
        V-72045
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
        Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nosuid" option on file systems that are being imported via NFS.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1186
        Result:true
        Title:Mount Remote Filesystems with nosuid
        Description:The nosuid option should be enabled for all NFS mounts in /etc/fstab.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (all nfs in /etc/fstab has nosuid)
          • true (all nfs has nosuid)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1188 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:all nfs in /etc/fstab has nosuid
        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2930 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
        • instance must not be equal to '0'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2931 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*nosuid.*$'
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8666900 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:all nfs has nosuid
        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8666900 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/mtab'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
        • instance must not be equal to '0'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2931 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*nosuid.*$'

        V-204483 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent binary files from being executed on file systems that are being imported via Network File System (NFS).

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204483r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-021021
        Identities:SV-87813
        V-73161
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
        Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "noexec" option on file systems that are being imported via NFS.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1178
        Result:true
        Title:Mount Remote Filesystems with noexec
        Description:The noexec option should be enabled for all NFS mounts in /etc/fstab.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (all nfs in /etc/fstab has noexec)
          • true (all nfs in /etc/mtab has noexec)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1180 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:all nfs in /etc/fstab has noexec
        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2921 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
        • instance must not be equal to '0'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2922 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*noexec.*$'
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8781300 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:all nfs in /etc/mtab has noexec
        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8781300 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/mtab'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\[?[\.\w:-]+\]?:[/\w-]+\s+[/\w-]+\s+nfs[4]?\s+(.*)$'
        • instance must not be equal to '0'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2922 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.*noexec.*$'

        V-204487 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that all world-writable directories are group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application group.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204487r744106_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-021030
        Identities:V-72047
        SV-86671
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: If a world-writable directory is not group-owned by root, sys, bin, or an application Group Identifier (GID), unauthorized users may be able to modify files created by others.

        The only authorized public directories are those temporary directories supplied with the system or those designed to be temporary file repositories. The setting is normally reserved for directories used by the system and by users for temporary file storage, (e.g., /tmp), and for directories requiring global read/write access. false
        Fix Text:All directories in local partitions which are world-writable should be group-owned by root or another system account. If any world-writable directories are not group-owned by a system account, this should be investigated. Following this, the directories should be deleted or assigned to an appropriate group.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1009
        Result:true
        Title:Find world writable directories not group-owned by a system account
        Description:All world writable directories should be group-owned by a system user.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
          • false (check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1010 (file_test)
        Result:false
        Title:check for local directories that are world writable and have gid greater than or equal to 1000
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2783 (file_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • behavior requirements:
          • recurse_file_system = local
          • recurse_direction = down
          • recurse = directories
        • path must be equal to '/'
        Include Items If:
        • group_id is greater than or equal to '1000'
        • owrite equals 'true'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2784 (file_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', group_id must be greater than or equal to '1000'
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', owrite must be equal to 'true'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204490 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the cron.allow file, if it exists, is owned by root.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204490r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-021110
        Identities:V-72053
        SV-86677
        CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
        Description: If the owner of the "cron.allow" file is not set to root, the possibility exists for an unauthorized user to view or to edit sensitive information. false
        Fix Text:Set the owner on the "/etc/cron.allow" file to root with the following command:

        # chown root /etc/cron.allow
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

        appropriate user.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (Testing user ownership of /etc/cron.allow)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:117 (file_test)
        Result:true

        Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.

        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', user_id must be equal to '0'

        V-204491 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the cron.allow file, if it exists, is group-owned by root.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204491r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-021120
        Identities:SV-86679
        V-72055

        Description: If the group owner of the "cron.allow" file is not set to root, sensitive information could be viewed or edited by unauthorized users. false

        V-204503 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that auditing is configured to produce records containing information to establish what type of events occurred, where the events occurred, the source of the events, and the outcome of the events. These audit records must also identify individual identities of group account users.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204503r603261_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-030000
        Identities:SV-86703
        V-72079
        CCI-000126 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-2.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-2 c)
        CCI-000131 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-3.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-3 b)
        Description: Without establishing what type of events occurred, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events leading up to an outage or attack.

        Audit record content that may be necessary to satisfy this requirement includes, for example, time stamps, source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.

        Associating event types with detected events in the operating system audit logs provides a means of investigating an attack; recognizing resource utilization or capacity thresholds; or identifying an improperly configured operating system.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000038-GPOS-00016, SRG-OS-000039-GPOS-00017, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00021, SRG-OS-000254-GPOS-00095, SRG-OS-000255-GPOS-00096 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to produce audit records containing information to establish when (date and time) the events occurred.

        Enable the auditd service with the following command:

        # systemctl start auditd.service
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86703
        Result:true
        Title:The audit service must be running.
        Description:Auditing must be configured to produce records containing information to establish what type of events occurred, where the events occurred, the source of the events, and the outcome of the events.

        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (check for auditd)

        V-204504 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must shut down upon audit processing failure, unless availability is an overriding concern. If availability is a concern, the system must alert the designated staff (System Administrator [SA] and Information System Security Officer [ISSO] at a minimum) in the event of an audit processing failure.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204504r880761_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030010
        Identities:V-72081
        SV-86705
        CCI-000139 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-5.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 a)
        Description: It is critical for the appropriate personnel to be aware if a system is at risk of failing to process audit logs as required. Without this notification, the security personnel may be unaware of an impending failure of the audit capability, and system operation may be adversely affected.

        Audit processing failures include software/hardware errors, failures in the audit capturing mechanisms, and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded.

        This requirement applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct information system component where audit records are stored), the centralized audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined), or both.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000046-GPOS-00022, SRG-OS-000047-GPOS-00023 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to shut down in the event of an audit processing failure.

        Add or correct the option to shut down the operating system with the following command:

        # auditctl -f 2

        Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

        -f 2

        If availability has been determined to be more important, and this decision is documented with the ISSO, configure the operating system to notify system administration staff and ISSO staff in the event of an audit processing failure with the following command:

        # auditctl -f 1

        Edit the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file and add the following line:

        -f 1

        Kernel log monitoring must also be configured to properly alert designated staff.

        The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:776
        Result:false
        Title:Shutdown System When Auditing Failures Occur
        Description:The system will shutdown when auditing fails.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit augenrules configuration shutdown)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (audit augenrules)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (audit auditctl configuration shutdown)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:777 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:audit augenrules configuration shutdown
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2600 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\-f\s*2\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:545 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:audit augenrules
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2427 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/usr/lib/systemd/system/auditd.service'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^ExecStartPost=\-\/sbin\/augenrules.*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ not evaluated ]
        • filepath equals '/usr/lib/systemd/system/auditd.service'
        • path equals '/usr/lib/systemd/system'
        • filename equals 'auditd.service'
        • pattern equals '^ExecStartPost=\-\/sbin\/augenrules.*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'ExecStartPost=-/sbin/augenrules --load'
        • line equals 'ExecStartPost=-/sbin/augenrules --load'
        • subexpression does not exist
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:778 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:audit auditctl configuration shutdown
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2601 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*\-f\s*2\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:543 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false

        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.

        • pattern must match the pattern '^ExecStartPost=\-\/sbin\/auditctl.*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204506 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured to off-load audit logs onto a different system or storage media from the system being audited.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204506r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030201
        Identities:SV-95729
        V-81017
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

        Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

        One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. Without the configuration of the "au-remote" plugin, the audisp-remote daemon will not off load the logs from the system being audited.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
        Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf file and add or update the following values:

        active = yes
        direction = out
        path = /sbin/audisp-remote
        type = always

        The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

        # service auditd restart
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95729
        Result:false
        Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must configure the au-remote plugin to off-load audit logs using the audisp-remote daemon.
        Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must configure the au-remote plugin to off-load audit logs using the audisp-remote daemon.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf active = yes)
          • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf direction = out)
          • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf path = /sbin/audisp-remote)
          • false (/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf type = always)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9572700 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf active = yes
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9572700 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • behavior requirements:
          • ignore_case = true
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/plugins.d/au-remote.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ ]*active[ ]+=[ ]+([^ ]*)[ ]*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:9572700 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Yy][Ee][Ss]$'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9572900 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false

        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.

        V-204507 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the remote logging buffer is full.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204507r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-030210
        Identities:V-81019
        SV-95731
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

        Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

        One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. When the remote buffer is full, audit logs will not be collected and sent to the central log server.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
        Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "overflow_action" option:

        overflow_action = syslog

        The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

        # service auditd restart
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95731
        Result:true
        Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the audisp-remote buffer is full.
        Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must take appropriate action when the audisp-remote buffer is full.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • true (Check the value assigned to overflow_action in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9573100 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:Check the value assigned to overflow_action in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9573100 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*overflow_action[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:9573100 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^syslog|single|halt$'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
        • path equals '/etc/audisp'
        • filename equals 'audispd.conf'
        • pattern equals '(?i)^\s*overflow_action[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'overflow_action = SYSLOG
          '
        • line equals 'overflow_action = SYSLOG
          '
        • subexpression equals 'SYSLOG'

        V-204508 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204508r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-030211
        Identities:SV-95733
        V-81021
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

        Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

        One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. When audit logs are not labeled before they are sent to a central log server, the audit data will not be able to be analyzed and tied back to the correct system.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
        Fix Text:Edit the /etc/audisp/audispd.conf file and add or update the "name_format" option:

        name_format = hostname

        The audit daemon must be restarted for changes to take effect:

        # service auditd restart
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:95733
        Result:true
        Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.
        Description:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must label all off-loaded audit logs before sending them to the central log server.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • true (Check the value assigned to name_format in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:9573300 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:Check the value assigned to name_format in /etc/audisp/audispd.conf
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:9573300 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*name_format[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:9573300 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?i)^hostname|fqd|numeric$'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/audisp/audispd.conf'
        • path equals '/etc/audisp'
        • filename equals 'audispd.conf'
        • pattern equals '(?i)^\s*name_format[ ]*=[ ]*([\w]+)\s*'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'name_format = HOSTNAME
          '
        • line equals 'name_format = HOSTNAME
          '
        • subexpression equals 'HOSTNAME'

        V-204509 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204509r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030300
        Identities:V-72083
        SV-86707
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

        Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

        Set the remote server option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" with the IP address of the log aggregation server.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA

        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899

        Result:false
        Title:The operating system must off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.
        Description:The operating system must off-load audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf remote_system is not empty)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8670700 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf remote_system is not empty
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8670700 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • behavior requirements:
          • ignore_case = true
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ ]*remote_server[ ]+=[ ]+(.*)'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8670700 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^.+$'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204510 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must encrypt the transfer of audit records off-loaded onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204510r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030310
        Identities:V-72085
        SV-86709
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Information stored in one location is vulnerable to accidental or incidental deletion or alteration.

        Off-loading is a common process in information systems with limited audit storage capacity.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000342-GPOS-00133, SRG-OS-000479-GPOS-00224 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to encrypt the transfer of off-loaded audit records onto a different system or media from the system being audited.

        Uncomment the "enable_krb5" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it with the following line:

        enable_krb5 = yes

        V-204511 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the audit system takes appropriate action when the audit storage volume is full.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204511r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030320
        Identities:V-72087
        SV-86711
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Taking appropriate action in case of a filled audit storage volume will minimize the possibility of losing audit records.
        One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. false
        Fix Text:Configure the action the operating system takes if the disk the audit records are written to becomes full.

        Uncomment or edit the "disk_full_action" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it to "syslog", "single", or "halt", such as the following line:

        disk_full_action = single
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86711
        Result:false
        Title:The audit system must take appropriate action when the audit storage volume is full.
        Description:The audit system must take appropriate action when the audit storage volume is full.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf disk_full_action = syslog, single, or halt)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8671100 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf disk_full_action = syslog, single, or halt
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        State Operator:One or more item-state comparisons may be true.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8671100 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • behavior requirements:
          • ignore_case = true
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*disk_full_action\s+=\s+(\S+)\s*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671100 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Ss][Yy][Ss][Ll][Oo][Gg]$'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671101 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Ss][Ii][Nn][Gg][Ll][Ee]$'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671102 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[Hh][Aa][Ll][Tt]$'
        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204512 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the audit system takes appropriate action when there is an error sending audit records to a remote system.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204512r877390_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030321
        Identities:V-73163
        SV-87815
        CCI-001851 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-4 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-4 (1))
        Description: Taking appropriate action when there is an error sending audit records to a remote system will minimize the possibility of losing audit records.
        One method of off-loading audit logs in Red Hat Enterprise Linux is with the use of the audisp-remote dameon. false
        Fix Text:Configure the action the operating system takes if there is an error sending audit records to a remote system.

        Uncomment the "network_failure_action" option in "/etc/audisp/audisp-remote.conf" and set it to "syslog", "single", or "halt".

        network_failure_action = syslog

        V-204514 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) via email when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204514r877389_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030340
        Identities:V-72091
        SV-86715
        CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
        Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached, they are unable to expand the audit record storage capacity before records are lost. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

        Uncomment or edit the "space_left_action" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to "email".

        space_left_action = email
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:86715
        Result:false
        Title:The operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) via email when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.
        Description:The operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) via email when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (All child checks must be true.)
          • false (/etc/audit/auditd.conf space_left_action = email)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8671500 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:/etc/audit/auditd.conf space_left_action = email
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8671500 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • behavior requirements:
          • ignore_case = true
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ ]*space_left_action[ ]+=[ ]+([^ ]*)[ ]*$'
        • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8671500 (textfilecontent54_state)

        • path equals '/etc/audit'

        • text equals 'space_left_action = SYSLOG'
        • line equals 'space_left_action = SYSLOG'
        • subexpression equals 'SYSLOG'
        Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
        subexpression

        V-204515 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must immediately notify the System Administrator (SA) and Information System Security Officer (ISSO) (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204515r877389_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Pass
        Version:RHEL-07-030350
        Identities:V-72093
        SV-86717
        CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
        Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached, they are unable to expand the audit record storage capacity before records are lost. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when the threshold for the repository maximum audit record storage capacity is reached.

        Uncomment or edit the "action_mail_acct" keyword in "/etc/audit/auditd.conf" and set it to root and any other accounts associated with security personnel.

        action_mail_acct = root
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:885
        Result:true
        Title:Auditd Email Account to Notify Upon Action
        Description:action_mail_acct setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to a certain account
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • true (All child checks must be true.)
          • true (email account for actions)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:886 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:true
        Title:email account for actions
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2688 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[ ]*action_mail_acct[ ]+=[ ]+(\S+)[ ]*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'
        State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2689 (textfilecontent54_state)
        State Requirements:
        • for check = 'all', subexpression, the following must be true:
          • subexpression must be equal to 'root'
        Collected Item/State Result:
        [ true ]
        • filepath equals '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
        • path equals '/etc/audit'
        • filename equals 'auditd.conf'
        • pattern equals '^[ ]*action_mail_acct[ ]+=[ ]+(\S+)[ ]*$'
        • instance equals '1'
        • text equals 'action_mail_acct = root'
        • line equals 'action_mail_acct = root'
        • subexpression equals 'root'

        V-204516 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all executions of privileged functions.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204516r853914_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030360
        Identities:V-72095
        SV-86719
        CCI-002234 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-6 (9); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-6 (9))
        Description: Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised information system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have significant adverse impacts on organizations. Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse and identify the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat. false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to audit the execution of privileged functions.

        Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

        -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid
        -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C uid!=euid -F euid=0 -k setuid
        -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid
        -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S execve -C gid!=egid -F egid=0 -k setgid

        The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:710
        Result:false
        Title:The Red Hat EnterpriseLinux Operating system must audit all executions of privileged functions.
        Description:Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised information system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have a significant adverse impacts on orginizations.
        Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse and identify the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)

                • false (audit augenrules execve gid 64-bit)

                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (64 bit architecture)
                • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
            • false (audit augenrules execve uid 32-bit)
            • false (audit augenrules execve gid 32-bit)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (audit augenrules)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)

                • false (audit auditctl execve gid 64-bit)

        V-204517 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat, and lchown syscalls.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204517r809570_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030370
        Identities:SV-86721
        V-72097
        CCI-000126 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-2.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-2 d; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-2 c)
        CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
        Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000474-GPOS-00219 false
        Fix Text:Add or update the following rule in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

        -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:552
        Result:false
        Title:RHEL-07-030370 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat and lchown syscalls.
        Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.
        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit augenrules 64-bit chown)
              • false (audit augenrules 64-bit fchown)
              • false (audit augenrules 64-bit fchownat)
              • false (audit augenrules 64-bit lchown)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (64 bit architecture)
                • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
            • false (audit augenrules 32-bit chown)
            • false (audit augenrules 32-bit fchown)
            • false (audit augenrules 32-bit fchownat)
            • false (audit augenrules 32-bit lchown)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (audit augenrules)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit chown)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchown)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchownat)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit lchown)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (64 bit architecture)
                • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit chown)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchown)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchownat)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit lchown)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl)
        Tests:
        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:554 (textfilecontent54_test)
        Result:false
        Title:audit augenrules 64-bit chown
        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2433 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b64[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+chown[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])chown([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'

        • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b64[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+fchownat[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])fchownat([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'
        • instance must be equal to '1'

        Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:589 (textfilecontent54_test)

        Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
        Check:Result is based on check existence only.
        Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2461 (textfilecontent54_object)
        Object Requirements:
        • path must be equal to '/etc/audit/rules.d'
        • filename must match the pattern '.*\.rules$'
        • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*-a[\s]+always,exit[\s]+(?:.*-F[\s]+arch=b64[\s]+)(?:.*(-S[\s]+lchown[\s]+|([\s]+|[,])lchown([\s]+|[,])))(?:.*-F\s+auid>=1000[\s]+)(?:.*-F\s+auid!=(?:4294967295|-1|unset)[\s]+).*(-k[\s]+|-F[\s]+key=)[-\w]+[\s]*$'

        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204521 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chmod, fchmod, and fchmodat syscalls.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204521r809772_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030410
        Identities:SV-86729
        V-72105
        CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
        Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to generate audit records upon successful/unsuccessful attempts to use the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" syscalls.

        Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

        -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:546
        Result:false
        Title:RHEL-07-030410 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the chmod, fchmod and fchmodat syscalls.
        Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.
        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
        Class:compliance
        Tests:
        • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)

              • false (audit augenrules 64-bit fchmodat)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)

                • false (One or more child checks must be true.)

                  • false (64 bit architecture)

            • false (audit augenrules 32-bit fchmodat)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (audit augenrules)
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit chmod)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchmod)
              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit fchmodat)
              • false (One or more child checks must be true.) (negated)
                • true (All child checks must be true.)
                  • true (64 bit architecture)
                • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
                  • false (64 bit architecture)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit chmod)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchmod)
            • false (audit auditctl 32-bit fchmodat)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (audit auditctl)

        Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        V-204524 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the setxattr, fsetxattr, lsetxattr, removexattr, fremovexattr, and lremovexattr syscalls.

        Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204524r809775_rule
        Test Type:Automated
        Result:Fail
        Version:RHEL-07-030440
        Identities:SV-86735
        V-72111
        CCI-000172 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 c)
        Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.

        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

        Satisfies: SRG-OS-000458-GPOS-00203, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033 false
        Fix Text:Configure the operating system to generate audit records upon successful/unsuccessful attempts to use the "setxattr", "fsetxattr", "lsetxattr", "removexattr", "fremovexattr", and "lremovexattr" syscalls.

        Add or update the following rules in "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

        -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S setxattr,fsetxattr,lsetxattr,removexattr,fremovexattr,lremovexattr -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S setxattr,fsetxattr,lsetxattr,removexattr,fremovexattr,lremovexattr -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

        The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
        Severity:medium
        Weight:10.0
        Reference:
        Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Publisher:DISA
        Type:DPMS Target
        Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
        Identifier:2899
        Definitions:
        Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:607
        Result:false
        Title:RHEL-07-030440 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must audit all uses of the setxattr, fsetxattr, lsetxattr, removexattr, fremovexattr and lremovexattr syscalls.
        Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

        Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

        When a user logs on, the auid is set to the uid of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to -1. The auid representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals 4294967295. The audit system interprets -1, 4294967295, and "unset" in the same way.
        The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

              • false (audit auditctl 64-bit removexattr)
